text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought unconscious to the emergency ward. In order to rule out hypothermia, how will you best measure his temperature? Oral Rectal Infrared tympanic thermometer Axillary
explanation:
:
In the given clinical scenario, the rectal temperature would be the best site to measure the core body temperature.
At extremes of high or low temperatures, like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperature.
The infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is representative of the core body temperature. However, it often ends up measuring the temperature of the ear canal. This is because of inadequate insertion into the ear canal due to poor manufacturing design or the presence of cerumen. Hence, it is not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature.

text: A patient in the emergency ward stays still while lying supine and hesitates to move. He also has very shallow breathing. This attitude of the patient is most likely due to which of the following conditions? Renal colic Peritonitis Acute pancreatitis Meningitis
explanation:
:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonitis. A patient with peritonitis lies supine without movement and has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain.
Option A: In renal colic, patients have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain.
Option C: In acute pancreatitis, the patient usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest position because of abdominal pain.
Option D: Patients with meningitis present with neck stiffness.

text: An alcohol addict presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, he is found to have pallor. Peripheral smear showed macrocytes and anisocytosis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient? Atrophic glossitis Migratory glossitis Strawberry tongue Macroglossia
explanation:
:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia likely due to folate deficiency caused by alcohol addiction. Folate deficiency leads to atrophic glossitis because of damage to the epithelial surfaces.



Option B: Migratory glossitis / geographic tongue is due to rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis.


Option C: Strawberry tongue is due to the hypertrophy of fungiform papillae. It is seen in scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease.



Option D: Macroglossia is an abnormal enlargement of the tongue and can be congenital or acquired. New-onset macroglossia in adults is highly suggestive of amyloidosis.

text: A woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following may be responsible for the given symptoms except: Methemoglobin exceeds 1.5 gm% Sulfhemoglobin exceeds 0.5 gm% Reduced hemoglobin exceeds 2 gm% Oxygen saturation below 85%
explanation:
:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is seen when the concentration of deoxygenated or reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL.
Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin 0.5 gm%.
Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation <85%. In dark-skinned individuals, it may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%.
The types of cyanosis are:

text: Which of the following skin findings is not associated with an endocrine abnormality? Acanthosis nigricans Diffuse hyperpigmentation Casal’s necklace Purple striae
explanation:
:
Casal’s necklace is not associated with an endocrine abnormality. It is a feature of pellagra, which occurs due to the deficiency of niacin.
Option A: Acanthosis nigricans is seen in multiple endocrinopathies like acromegaly, Cushing’s syndrome, polycystic ovary syndrome, and insulin-resistant diabetes mellitus.
Option B: Diffuse hyperpigmentation is seen in Addison’s disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome. Option D: Purple striae are seen in Cushing’s disease.

text: What are petechiae? Large extravasation of blood in the skin Skin hemorrhages measuring 2-3 mm Skin hemorrhages measuring 1-2 mm Skin hemorrhages measuring 3-4 mm
explanation:
:
Petechiae are defined as skin hemorrhages appearing as minute non-blanching spots that measure less than 2 mm.
A few conditions causing petechiae have been stated below:
Infectious diseases: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, infective endocarditis, meningococcemia, and viral hemorrhagic fevers.
Non-infectious conditions: Vasculitis, thrombocytopenia, leukemia, scurvy, and vitamin K deficiency
Drugs: Anticoagulants (warfarin, heparin), quinine, etc.
Large extravasation of blood in the skin is known as ecchymosis.
Purpura are also non-blanching spots but unlike petechiae, they measure  3 mm in size.

text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following conditions is/are associated with this lesion? 1 and 5 2, 3 and 5 1, 3 and 4 1, 2 and 4
explanation:
:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi (nevus araneus). They are seen in:
Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use

Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease
Thyrotoxicosis
They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the centre outward.

text: You observed the following finding in a patient in the OPD. Which among the following conditions is least likely to cause this finding? Endocarditis Bronchiectasis Tricuspid atresia Aortic dissection
explanation:
:
The given image shows digital clubbing. Among the given options, aortic dissection is least likely to cause digital clubbing.
Clubbing is a selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes due to the proliferation of connective tissue, particularly on the dorsal surface.
Causes of clubbing are:
Pulmonary
Bronchogenic carcinoma
Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
Interstitial lung diseases
Cystic fibrosis
Sarcoidosis
Asbestosis
GI
Inflammatory bowel disease (Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease)
Sprue, celiac disease
Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
Cirrhosis - juvenile and biliary
Chronic active hepatitis
Cardiovascular
Cyanotic congenital heart disease
Subacute bacterial endocarditis
Aortic aneurysm
Arteriovenous fistula
Patent ductus arteriosus with right to left shunt
Atrial myxoma
Endocrine
Grave’s disease (thyroid acropachy)

CNS
Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
Skin disease
Palmoplantar keratoderma
Fischer-Volavsek syndrome.
Malignancies
Thyroid cancer
Thymus cancer
Hodgkin disease
Disseminated chronic myeloid leukemia.
Note: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) does not cause clubbing. If clubbing is present in a patient with COPD, underlying lung cancer and bronchiectasis must be ruled out.

text: A 40-year-old patient presents with loss of appetite, jaundice, and easy bruisability. He is a chronic alcohol user, and the following abnormality is noted on examination. What is the most likely cause of this nail change? Scurvy Hypoalbuminemia Chronic iron deficiency Folate deficiency
explanation:
:
The nail change seen in the given image is leukonychia totalis. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of liver cirrhosis, which leads to hypoalbuminemia.
Leukonychia is an opaque whitish discoloration of the nail and is seen in the following conditions:
Dietary deficiency: Protein-energy malnutrition, pellagra, zinc deficiency
Drugs: Cytotoxic agents, Steroids, Retinoids, Pilocarpine
Dermatological pathology: Alopecia areata, erythema multiforme, exfoliative dermatitis, and SLE
Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure
Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride)
Idiopathic
Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed leukonychia striata or Aldrich–Mees lines.

text: A resident is examining a patient with bilateral leg swelling below the knees. He notes that on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. What is the likely cause of the edema? Myxedema Nephrotic syndrome Chronic lymphangitis Acute lymphatic filariasis
explanation:
:
Bilateral non-pitting edema in the lower limbs is suggestive of myxedema.
While chronic lymphangitis and acute lymphatic filariasis can also cause non-pitting edema, they usually have a unilateral/localized presentation.
Nephrotic syndrome and heart failure cause bilateral pitting edema. Causes of generalized edema include:
Heart failure
Chronic renal failure
Nephrotic syndrome
Liver cirrhosis
Causes of localized edema include:
Thrombophlebitis
Chronic lymphangitis
Resection of regional lymph nodes
Filariasis

text: While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient? Left-sided heart failure Anemia Thiamine deficiency Aortic regurgitation
explanation:
:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse, which is not seen in left-sided heart failure.

Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.
The various causes of the collapsing pulse include
Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance.
Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva
High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism)

text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing
explanation:
:
Orthostatic hypotension or postural hypotension is defined as a sustained drop in systolic BP of
20 mmHg or diastolic BP of 10 mmHg after 3 min of standing.
It can manifest as lightheadedness/dizziness, weakness or tiredness, difficulty thinking/concentrating, blurred vision, and anxiety.
In non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension such as hypovolemia, the drop in the blood pressure is accompanied by a compensatory increase in heart rate of >15 beats/min. In neurogenic causes, there is aggravation or precipitation of orthostatic hypotension by autonomic stressors like a meal, hot bath, or exercise.
Non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension include
Cardiac pump failure - myocardial infarction, myocarditis, aortic stenosis
Hypovolemia - dehydration, diarrhea, hemorrhage
Metabolic - adrenocortical insufficiency, pheochromocytoma
Venous pooling - sepsis, prolonged standing, or recumbency
Medications - alpha-blockers, diuretics, phenothiazines, tricyclic antidepressants Treatment includes removing reversible causes like drugs causing hypotension.
Non-pharmacological interventions include patient education regarding staged moves from supine to upright, raising the head of the bed, and increasing dietary fluid and salt. If these fail, drugs like fludrocortisone and midodrine can be given.

text: A 30-year-old African farmer presents with Winterbottom’s sign. This sign is due to the involvement of: Deep cervical nodes Supraclavicular nodes Posterior cervical nodes Occipital nodes
explanation:
:
Winterbottom’s sign is due to the involvement of posterior cervical nodes. It is seen in African trypanosomiasis.
African trypanosomiasis is a vector born disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense/rhodesiense. It is transmitted through the bite of a Tsetse fly.

The clinical syndrome includes hemolymphatic disease with associated Winterbottom's sign and a maculopapular rash primarily involving the trunk. At a later stage, the patient can present with features suggestive of meningoencephalitis.

text: Relative bradycardia occurs in: Typhoid fever Q fever Leptospirosis All of the above
explanation:
:
In the given options typhoid, Q fever, and leptospirosis are infectious causes of relative bradycardia.
Relative bradycardia, also known as Faget's sign, is observed when patients exhibit a lower heart rate than anticipated in relation to an increase in body temperature. Body temperature is commonly regarded as a factor that independently influences heart rate. It is estimated that for each 1°C (1.8°F) rise in temperature, the heart rate typically increases by approximately 15-20 beats per minute.
While this pulse-temperature dissociation is not highly sensitive or specific for establishing a diagnosis, it can still prove beneficial in resource-limited settings due to its easy accessibility and simplicity.
Infectious causes of relative bradycardia include:
Salmonella typhi
Francisella tularensis
Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
Leptospira interrogans
Legionella pneumophila
Rickettsia spp.
Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
Corynebacterium diphtheriae
Plasmodium spp. (malaria)
Noninfectious causes include:
Drug fever
Beta-blocker use
Central nervous system lesions
Malignant lymphoma
Factitious fever

text: A patient with rheumatic heart disease now presents with fever and the following nail finding. The nail lesions most likely are? Roth spots Janeway lesions Osler nodes Splinter hemorrhages
explanation:
:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Splinter hemorrhages are seen in the nails of these patients.

Subungual splinter hemorrhages are classically identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed.
Other peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:
Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding
Purulent purpura
Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules usually found on the distal pads of the digits
Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles
Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers

text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found on his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis? Hand-foot-mouth disease Infective endocarditis Cat scratch disease Rocky Mountain Spotted fever
explanation:
:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is infective endocarditis.
Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.
Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:
Roth spots: These are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles. The image is shown below.

text: On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicate: Palpable S3 Palpable S4 Palpable murmur Palpable right ventricular systole
explanation:
:
On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicates a palpable murmur. Thrills are the palpable vibrations produced by turbulent blood flow causing murmurs.

Palpable S3 and S4 cause a double thrust in the apical impulse.
Palpable right ventricular systole is known as heave which is felt in the left parasternal area.

text: As an intern in the emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation? Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus Mouth to ear to umbilicus Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus
explanation:
:
The commonly used method to determine the length of a nasogastric tube is the NEX method: the tip of the nose to the ear to the xiphisternum.
The approximate length is 120-125 cm. The markings indicate the traversing of the tube through various parts of the GIT:
40 cm: Cardia of the stomach
50 cm: Body of the stomach
60 cm: Pylorus
70 cm: Duodenum
A nasogastric tube or Ryle's tube is inserted in the sitting position with the neck slightly flexed. The tube is then gently inserted through the nostril and advanced until it reaches 10 cm. The patient is encouraged to swallow, allowing the tube to move down the esophagus with successive swallows until it reaches the measured distance.
Subjective confirmation involves insufflating air through the proximal opening of the NG tube and listening for the sound of air in the left upper quadrant where the stomach is located. Objective confirmation can be obtained through pH measurement, chest or abdominal radiographs, ultrasound, or calorimetric capnometry.
While widely practiced, blind NG tube insertion can lead to complications such as coiling of the tube in the nasopharynx, incorrect placement in the bronchial passage, or even esophageal perforation.

text: A patient presents with excessive thirst, unexplained weight loss, visual blurring, genital thrush, and lethargy. What is the most likely diagnosis? Hyperglycemia Hyperthyroidism Hypoglycemia Diabetic neuropathy
explanation:
:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is hyperglycemia. The symptoms of hyperglycemia include:
Polyuria
Polydipsia
Weight loss
Fatigue
Blurry vision
Frequent superficial infections (vaginitis, fungal skin infections)
Slow healing of skin lesions after minor trauma.

Note: The metabolic derangements occurring in these patients are due to osmotic diuresis and a catabolic state caused by urinary loss of glucose and increased muscle breakdown. Blurred vision results from changes in the water content of the lens.

text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is 37 degree C 42 degree C 32 Degree C 30 degree C
explanation:
:
The temperature of the water bath for a patient with frostbite should be maintained between 37- 40°C (Option A). Circulating water is preferred for treatment.
In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vasoconstriction. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.
The treatment includes - extraction from cold environment, rapid rewarming, analgesics for pain during thawing, antithrombotics or thrombolytics, cleaning of the injured area with soap or antiseptics, tetanus prophylaxis, monitoring for compartment syndrome and finally, elective late amputation after imaging in severe cases.

Answer Key



Detailed Explanations

Solution to Question 1:
The most effective extracellular buffer system at physiological pH is the bicarbonate buffer system.
A molecule with a pKa close to the physiological pH (7.4) is considered an effective buffer. Although the pKa of HCO3- is relatively low (6.1), it makes up 92% of the plasma buffering.
This is often attributed to the enormous quantity of HCO3- present in the body and the ability of this system to accept protons and form carbonic acid (H2CO3). This further in the presence of carbonic anhydrase is converted to readily excretable H■O and CO2. It is therefore considered the most efficient extracellular buffering system in the body.
HCO3- + H+	H2CO3 	H■O + CO2



Solution to Question 2:
Flexion of the wrist is not done just before drawing blood for ABG analysis.
During arterial blood gas analysis, the ideal position for drawing arterial blood from the radial artery is to maintain the wrist in extension. This provides stability to the artery and prevents it from slipping away during the puncture. To draw blood for ABG analysis, the skin is pierced at a 45° angle.


Allen's test is done prior to radial cannulation to identify the adequacy of radial and ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand.



The syringe used to draw blood for ABG analysis is rinsed with heparin prior to the procedure. Prior to collecting blood, 0.1 ml heparin is drawn into the syringe and then flushed
out. The residue that lubricates the inner wall of the syringe is sufficient to prevent the blood from clotting.

While hypercalcemia can be a cause of metabolic alkalosis, alkalosis itself can cause a decrease in ionized calcium. The patients can present with tetany and show signs of hypocalcemia, i.e., Trousseau sign and Chvostek's sign.
Conn's syndrome is primary hyperaldosteronism that leads to sodium reabsorption in exchange for hydrogen in the collecting ducts. This causes hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hydrogen loss in urine and may lead to metabolic alkalosis.

Solution to Question 6:
Among the given options, high pH (7.55), high HCO3- (30 mEq/L), and high pCO2 (48 mmHg) is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis with respiratory acidosis, as a result of compensatory hypoventilation.
Multiple episodes of vomiting result in loss of acids from the body and thus increases the pH.






Solution to Question 7:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.
Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis.
Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic alkalosis.
Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.
Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:
On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3-
In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L)
Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 = 12 mmHg
Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg.
As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.



Solution to Question 8:
The patient has low pH and decreased levels of bicarbonate which is indicative of metabolic acidosis. Bicarbonate reabsorption is increased in renal handling of metabolic acidosis.
In response to metabolic acidosis, acidification of urine occurs by the following compensatory mechanisms:
The proximal tubule reabsorbs all the filtered HCO3- (as any loss of HCO3- is equal to the addition of an equimolar amount of H+).

The collecting duct excretes the daily H+ load (loss of H+ is equal to the addition of an equimolar amount of HCO3-) primarily in the form of urinary ammonia.



Solution to Question 9:
The anion gap is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:
Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma.
However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl and HCO3. The value of plasma potassium is omitted from the calculation of the anion gap.
Usually, the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations.
The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall.
The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions. The unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium, and potassium.

Solution to Question 12:
Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap is a feature of renal tubular acidosis.
Renal tubular acidosis is a form of hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis which occurs when the renal damage primarily affects tubular function without much effect on glomerular function. The bicarbonate loss leading to acidosis is mirrored by an increase in chloride concentration. Hence the unmeasured anions are unaffected and thus, the anion gap remains within normal limits.
The result is a decrease in H+ excretion which is greater than that can be explained by any change in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). However, if the GFR is significantly depressed eg., renal failure, the retention of fixed acids leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

It is used in the presence of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), to check it is a ‘pure’ HAGMA or if there is coexistant normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) or metabolic alkalosis.

1-2 indicates HAGMA
< 1 indicates NAGMA + HAGMA

Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. This leads to a decrease in serum albumin which is an unmeasured anion.

Albumin at physiological pH is the major contributor to the unmeasured anions of the body. Unmeasured anions consume bicarbonate in the body and reduce its levels. This leads to an increase in the anion gap. Therefore, when these unmeasured anions are reduced the anion gap also reduces due to decreased consumption of the bicarbonate.
Nephrotic syndrome causes hypoalbuminemia and thus patients have a reduced anion gap. A fall in serum albumin by 1 g/dL from the normal value (4.5 g/dL) decreases the anion gap by 2.5 mEq/L.
Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen in:
Increase in unmeasured cations
An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as:
Lithium (lithium intoxication)
Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
Reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)
Bromide intoxication
Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia, which can lead to an underestimation of sodium and chloride concentrations.

Solution to Question 17:
The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.
Interpretation of the ABG:
Step 1: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis.
Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis.
Step 3: pCO2 is 16 mmHg indicating respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in pCO2 along with the decrease in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.
Step 4: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula
(Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2).
Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19 mmHg
A pCO2 level of 16 mmHg falls within the range given above. Hence, metabolic acidosis is associated with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

(pCO2 values above or below 15 - 19 mmHg would indicate mixed acid-base disorders) Alternatively:
The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.2 mmHg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.
The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.2 = 22
Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22 = 18 mmHg (roughly = 16 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)
This method also indicates primary metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.
